Subjective: Right low back pain for 1.5 weeks, progressively worsening. Radiates down posterior and lateral right leg to the foot. Pain is constant and severe. Associated tingling in the same distribution. Sensation on the outer right lower leg feels 'duller'. No weakness, but pain limits movement. Pertinent negatives: No saddle anesthesia, no bowel or bladder dysfunction. Tried max dose paracetamol and ibuprofen with no relief. Impact: Unable to sleep for nights due to pain. Stopped working at supermarket (job involves heavy lifting). Unable to exercise. Social: Works in a supermarket. ICE: Concerned about severity and duration; neighbor required surgery for similar issue. Wants to get rid of the pain; asks about needing a CT or MRI scan.
Objective: General: Obvious pain with movement, especially getting on exam table. Back Exam: No visible abnormalities. No vertebral tenderness to palpation. Tenderness noted more towards right gluteal area. Neurological Exam: Sensation decreased ('dull feeling') on the right leg compared to left. Motor strength 5/5 and symmetric in all lower extremity muscle groups, though movement is painful on the right. Reflexes: Normal and symmetric. Special Tests: Straight Leg Raise positive on the right, negative on the left.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, secondary to suspected herniated disc (hernia). No clinical signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Medication: Start pregabalin for neuropathic pain; build up dose slowly. 2. Counseling: Explained hernia diagnosis, nerve compression mechanism, and typical recovery timeline (weeks to months). Discussed conservative management (physio, pain relief) as first-line over surgery. Advised no driving for at least one week after starting or increasing pregabalin dose. 3. Referral: Recommend physiotherapy for guided exercises. 4. Safety Netting: Return immediately or contact GP out-of-hours service for new/worsening saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder incontinence, or significant leg weakness. 5. Follow-up: Telephone appointment in one week to review pain control and medication tolerance.
